Apply to Reading and Writing (10 MIN.)
Read: Country Mouse and City Mouse
Guide students through a reading of Country Mouse and City Mouse.
Write to Deepen Comprehension: Personal Response
Have students write whether City Mouse will visit Country Mouse again.
Allow students to orally share with a partner what they want to write before writing.
Prompt them to look back at the story for support in writing.
Students can complete the writing during independent work time.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that this story has two different settingsthe country and the city.
Have students share what they know about each setting.
Introduce the word perspective using the Define/Example/Ask routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
is a way of thinking about something.
about how a new park would benefit the local community.
on year-round school? Are you for it or against it?
Have students whisper-read the story. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the sentence that tells why City Mouse wants to show Country Mouse the city. (Youll see what good living is all about!)
What is Country Mouses perspective on the city? Find the sentences that answer the question.
How are the city and country alike? How are they different?
Would you prefer to live in the city or the country? Why?
Have students reread the story during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.

Morphology: Inflectional Endings with Spelling Changes
Use the Phonics/Syllable Cards or write the inflectional endings -ed and -ing. Read each one and have students repeat.

Review that -ed and -ing are inflectional endings that change a base words meaning, tense, or part of speech. Some words require spelling changes before adding the ending. For example, when the base word ends in e, drop the e and add the ending.
Model how to add -ed to smile to form the word smiled. Point out the spelling change and have students read the new word. Repeat with -ing to form smiling.
Then review that some base words require the final consonant to be doubled before adding the -ed or -ing ending.
Model how to add -ed to skip to form the word skipped. Point out the spelling change and have students read the new word. Repeat with -ing to form skipping.

Continue by adding -ed and -ing to these words: drop (dropped, dropping), note (noted, noting), hurry (hurried, hurrying), joke (joked, joking). Guide students to read the words and identify the spelling changes to the base word.

Use Supports for Segmenting and Manipulating Sounds
Prompt students to mark the sounds, such as by tapping or using counters, when they need support orally segmenting the word before writing it.
You can also model by moving one colored square or block for each sound or syllable when manipulating (adding, deleting, substituting) sounds during word building exercises.
For example, have students move up one purple square. Say:
This is the /a/ square. Add a square to show me at.
Students should add a different color square after the purple /a/ square. Say:
. Students should add a different color square before the purple /a/ square.
High-Frequency Word Sentences in Writers Notebook
Each week, have students write one sentence for each high-frequency word in a section of a writers notebook.
Then have students read their sentences from the beginning of the year to a partner. This will increase the amount of times they see the word in context, getting to mastery faster.

Morphology: Contractions with ll, ve, m
Then write the contraction Ill. Read it, and have students repeat.

Review that a contraction is a shortened way of saying two words. The apostrophe takes the place of the letter(s) that drop from the second word when it is shortened. Contractions are commonly used with the words will, have, and am.
Point out that the contraction Ill is a short form of I will. The space between words is removed, and the letters wi in will are replaced by the apostrophe.
Continue by forming contractions for the following: they have (theyve), she will (shell), I am (Im). Guide students to read the contractions and determine which letter(s) the apostrophe replaces.
Then review how to form contractions with t and s: cannot (cant), it is (its), did not (didnt), and he is (hes).

Morphology: Inflectional Endings with Spelling Changes
Use the Phonics/Syllable Cards or write the inflectional endings -ed and -ing. Read each one and have students repeat.

Review that -ed and -ing are inflectional endings that change a base words meaning, tense, or part of speech. Some words require spelling changes before adding the ending. For example, when the base word ends in e, drop the e and add the ending.
Model how to add -ed to smile to form the word smiled. Point out the spelling change and have students read the new word. Repeat with -ing to form smiling.
Then review that some base words require the final consonant to be doubled before adding the -ed or -ing ending.
Model how to add -ed to skip to form the word skipped. Point out the spelling change and have students read the new word. Repeat with -ing to form skipping.

Continue by adding -ed and -ing to these words: drop (dropped, dropping), note (noted, noting), hurry (hurried, hurrying), joke (joked, joking). Guide students to read the words and identify the spelling changes to the base word.

Use Supports for Segmenting and Manipulating Sounds
Prompt students to mark the sounds, such as by tapping or using counters, when they need support orally segmenting the word before writing it.
You can also model by moving one colored square or block for each sound or syllable when manipulating (adding, deleting, substituting) sounds during word building exercises.
For example, have students move up one purple square. Say:
This is the /a/ square. Add a square to show me at.
Students should add a different color square after the purple /a/ square. Say:
. Students should add a different color square before the purple /a/ square.

Morphology: Contractions with ll, ve, m
Then write the contraction Ill. Read it, and have students repeat.

Review that a contraction is a shortened way of saying two words. The apostrophe takes the place of the letter(s) that drop from the second word when it is shortened. Contractions are commonly used with the words will, have, and am.
Point out that the contraction Ill is a short form of I will. The space between words is removed, and the letters wi in will are replaced by the apostrophe.
Continue by forming contractions for the following: they have (theyve), she will (shell), I am (Im). Guide students to read the contractions and determine which letter(s) the apostrophe replaces.
Then review how to form contractions with t and s: cannot (cant), it is (its), did not (didnt), and he is (hes).

Morphology: Inflectional Endings with Spelling Changes
Use the Phonics/Syllable Cards or write the inflectional endings -ed and -ing. Read each one and have students repeat.

Review that -ed and -ing are inflectional endings that change a base words meaning, tense, or part of speech. Some words require spelling changes before adding the ending. For example, when the base word ends in e, drop the e and add the ending.
Model how to add -ed to smile to form the word smiled. Point out the spelling change and have students read the new word. Repeat with -ing to form smiling.
Then review that some base words require the final consonant to be doubled before adding the -ed or -ing ending.
Model how to add -ed to skip to form the word skipped. Point out the spelling change and have students read the new word. Repeat with -ing to form skipping.

Continue by adding -ed and -ing to these words: drop (dropped, dropping), note (noted, noting), hurry (hurried, hurrying), joke (joked, joking). Guide students to read the words and identify the spelling changes to the base word.

Use Supports for Segmenting and Manipulating Sounds
Prompt students to mark the sounds, such as by tapping or using counters, when they need support orally segmenting the word before writing it.
You can also model by moving one colored square or block for each sound or syllable when manipulating (adding, deleting, substituting) sounds during word building exercises.
For example, have students move up one purple square. Say:
This is the /a/ square. Add a square to show me at.
Students should add a different color square after the purple /a/ square. Say:
. Students should add a different color square before the purple /a/ square.

Morphology: Contractions with ll, ve, m
Then write the contraction Ill. Read it, and have students repeat.

Review that a contraction is a shortened way of saying two words. The apostrophe takes the place of the letter(s) that drop from the second word when it is shortened. Contractions are commonly used with the words will, have, and am.
Point out that the contraction Ill is a short form of I will. The space between words is removed, and the letters wi in will are replaced by the apostrophe.
Continue by forming contractions for the following: they have (theyve), she will (shell), I am (Im). Guide students to read the contractions and determine which letter(s) the apostrophe replaces.
Then review how to form contractions with t and s: cannot (cant), it is (its), did not (didnt), and he is (hes).
